title-group.article-title: On the status of Helicops wettsteini Amaral, 1929, a senior synonym of Hypsiscopus murphyi (SERPENTES: Homalopsidae)

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
On the status of
Helicops wettsteini Amaral, 1929
, a senior synonym of
Hypsiscopus murphyi
(SERPENTES: Homalopsidae )

PATRICK DAVID 1* & GERNOT VOGEL 2
1
Institut de Systématique, Évolution et Biodiversité (ISYEB), Muséum National d’Histoire Naturelle, Sorbonne Université, École Pratique des Hautes Études, Université des Antilles, CNRS, CP 30, 57 rue Cuvier, F-75005 Paris, France .

Ễ
patrick.david@mnhn.fr; https://orcid.org/0000-0001-7562-684X 2
Society for Southeast Asian Herpetology, Im Sand 3, D-69115 Heidelberg, Germany .
Ễ gernot.vogel@t-online.de; https://orcid.org/0000-0002-4542-518X *Corresponding author

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
We redescribe the name-bearing types of
Helicops wettsteini Amaral, 1929
, a species described from central Costa Rica . However, while
Helicops wettsteini
has been considered in the literature a synonym of
Hypsiscopus plumbeus
(previously
Enhydris plumbea
), we present here morphological evidence for considering
Helicops wettsteini
a synonym of the recently described species
Hypsiscopus murphyi Bernstein, Voris, Stuart, Phimmachak, Seateun, Sivongxay, Neang, Karns, Andrews, Osterhage, Phipps & Ruane, 2022
, which hence becomes a junior subjective synonym of
Hypsiscopus wettsteini ( Amaral, 1929 )
.

sec.title: N/A
Introduction
sec.p:
described a new species of “colubrid”,
Helicops wettsteini
, based on two specimens originating from “San Juan de Viñas (1000 ms. alt.), base of Volcano Turialba, central Costa Rica ” (now Turrialba Volcano, Cartago Province , Costa Rica ), namely the holotype , NMW 18726:1, and the paratype , NMW 18726:2. Amaral examined these specimens during a visit to the collection of the “Naturhistorische Museum in Wien ”, namely the Museum of Natural History in Vienna , Austria .
published a detailed description of these specimens. Based on the Neotropical locality of these specimens, the shape of their head and body, and their head scalation, especially the single internasal, Amaral referred them to the Neotropical genus
Helicops Wagler, 1828
. He stressed the importance of this discovery, as the genus
Helicops
was, and is still unknown northeast of Colombia (Scĥneberg & K̂hler 2021). This genus currently includes 20 species, all inhabiting South America (Uetz et al . 2023).
Helicops wettsteini
was regarded as valid by
.

Subsequently,
were able to examine again the types of
Helicops wettsteini
. These authors pointed out that the general appearance of these specimens is “strikingly similar” to members of the genus
Helicops
. However, in examining their maxillary dentition, they noticed that it is opisthoglyphous, namely the enlarged posterior maxillary teeth are grooved, a character not present in the genus
Helicops
in which these maxillary teeth are enlarged but not grooved (
). As no other morphologically similar species is opisthoglyphous in Neotropical America,
concluded that the type locality in Costa Rica was erroneous. These authors compared with non-American species having a single internasal and found that the specimens of
Helicops wettsteini
agreed “in all respects” with
Enhydris plumbea
(H. Boie in F.
), a common Asian species then referred to the subfamily Homalopsinae of Colubridae . Therefore,
synonymized
Helicops wettsteini Amaral, 1929
with
Enhydris plumbea
.

This synonymy was accepted by
and
, but it was seemingly overlooked, or at least not mentioned by
,
,
and, more important as we will see below, by
.

On another side,
revised the homalopsid snakes, which they considered as a full family. They divided into several genera the large genus
Enhydris Latreille
in Sonnini & Latreille, 1801, shown to be polyphyletic. One of them was
Hypsiscopus Fitzinger, 1843
( type species:
Homalopsis plumbea H. Boie
in F.
, by original designation), a genus-level nomen described as a subgenus of
Hydropsis Fitzinger, 1843
, itself a junior synonym of the genus
Fordonia Gray, 1842
( Homalopsidae ).
Hypsiscopus
has long been considered a synonym of
Enhydris
or of
Hypsirhina Wagler, 1830
, a junior synonym of
Enhydris
.
resurrected
Hypsiscopus
from this synonymy to accommodate two species,
Hypsiscopus plumbeus
(H. Boie in F.
) (not
plumbea
, as
Hypsiscopus
is masculine in gender) and
Hypsiscopus matannensis (Boulenger, 1897)
.

Subsequently, based on molecular analyses,
, confirmed by
, found that
Hypsiscopus plumbeus
is paraphyletic with respect to
Hypsiscopus matannensis
, a species inhabiting Sulawesi ( Indonesia ), with populations of Central Thailand and most of Indochinese region and southern China phylogenetically outside of the clade containing
H. matannensis
and populations of
H. plumbeus
inhabiting southern Thailand and the Sunda Region.
found that specimens referred to this lineage differed morphologically and genetically from
H. plumbeus sensu stricto
. Based on its phylogenetic position and morphological characters,
described this lineage as a distinct species,
Hypsiscopus murphyi Bernstein, Voris, Stuart, Phimmachak, Seateun, Sivongxay, Neang, Karns, Andrews, Osterhage, Phipps & Ruane, 2022
. Subsequently,
described
Hypsiscopus indonesiensis
for a population of Sulawesi. The genus
Hypsiscopus
currently contains only these four species (Uetz et al . 2023).

We here compare the main morphological characters of the name-bearing types of
Helicops wettsteini
with the diagnostic characters of the three recognized species of the genus
Hypsiscopus
. Based on these external characters, we discuss the systematic status of
Helicops wettsteini
.

sec.title: Material and Methods
sec.p:
Although this analysis of the morphological characters in the genus
Hypsiscopus
is mainly based on
, we examined the two types of
Helicops wettsteini
, as well as 45 specimens of
Hysiscopus murphyi
and 10 specimens of
Hypsiscopus plumbeus
according to the definition of
. These specimens are listed in Appendix I.

Measurements, except body and tail lengths, were taken with a slide-caliper to the nearest 0.1 millimeter ; all body measurements were made to the nearest millimeter. The number of ventral scales was counted according to Dowling (1951). The terminal scute is not included in the number of subcaudals. The dorsal scale row counts are given at one head length behind head, at midbody (i.e., at the level of the ventral plate corresponding to a half of the total number of ventrals), and at one head length before vent. Values for paired head characters are given in the left/right order.

sec.title: Abbreviations of measurements and morphological characters:
sec.p: Body . SVL: snout-vent length.—TaL: tail length.—TL: total length.—DSR: dorsal scale rows.—SC: subcaudal scales.— VEN : ventral scales.

Head . DE: diameter of the eye (vertical).—DE-L: distance between the lower margin of the eye and the edge of the lip.—DE-N: distance eye-nostril (from the anterior margin of the eye).—HL: head length (from tip of the snout to the angle of jaws).—HW: head width (at the level of the anterior margin of the eyes).—IL: infralabial scales.—InN: internasal scale.—SL: supralabial scales (SL in contact with eye).—SnL: snout length (from the tip of the snout to the anterior margin of the eye).

Museum abbreviations :
MNHN : Muséum National d’Histoire Naturelle, Paris, France .—NCSM. North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences Raleigh, North Carolina , USA
.—
NMW : Naturhistorisches Museum Wien , Vienna , Austria .—RMNH
.
RENA : Naturalis Biodiversity Center (formerly the Nationaal Natuurhistorisch Museum), Leiden, The Netherlands
.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
Redescription of the name-bearing types of
Helicops wettsteini
Both specimens, holotype and paratype , are in very good condition.
Holotype . NMW 18726:1 ( Figs. 1A–1D )
Measurements . Female; SVL 304 mm , TaL 50 mm , TL 354 mm ; ratio TaL/TL 0.141; HL 18.9 mm ; HW 11.9 mm ; DE: 2.2 mm ; DE-L 2.3 mm ; DE-N 2.6 mm .

Morphology . Body stout, slightly vertically compressed; head small, elongate, oval, thick, moderately distinct from the thick neck; snout average in length, namely 1.9 times as long as the horizontal diameter of the eye, depressed anteriorly, rounded seen from above, oblique in profile view; no canthus rostralis ; nostril directed dorsally, small, round, piercing in the middle of a semi-divided nasal scale; eye small, placed high on the side of the head and directed dorsolaterally, its diameter 0.9 times the distance between the lower margin of the eye and the edge of the lip, with a vertically elliptical pupil; tail short, thinner than the body and tapering.

Body scalation . Dorsal scales in 19 - 19 - 17 rows, normal in shape, all smooth; scales of the 1st DSR distinctly enlarged; 128 ventral plates (plus 1 preventral); 38 subcaudals, paired; cloacal plate divided.

Head scalation . Arrangement of cephalic scales complete, including 1 single internasal, 2 prefrontals, 2 supraoculars, 1 frontal, and 2 parietals. Rostral pentagonal, wider than high but relatively short, visible from above; 1 nasal on each sides, pentagonal, wide, placed dorsally, semi-divided by a shallow suture extending below the nostril that touches the 1st SL; 1 single internasal, triangular, its apex pointing forwards between the two nasals, shorter than these latter scales but much longer than the suture between nasals, 1.8 times wider than long, not in contact with the loreal; 2 prefrontals, large, pentagonal, wider than long, 1.1 times as long as the internasal, in contact with the loreal and the preocular; frontal hexagonal, elongate, bell-shaped, relatively wide, pointing backwards, 1.5 times longer than wide, 2.4 times longer than the prefrontals; on each side, a subrectangular supraocular, relatively small, narrower anteriorly than posteriorly, 1.9 times longer than wide, 0.6 times as wide as the frontal; parietals large, elongate, in broad contact with each other, 1.6 times longer than the frontal, the suture between them as long as the frontal; 1 large occipital scale behind the posterior edge of each parietal; 1 loreal on each side, relatively large, pentagonal, slightly higher than long, in contact with 2nd–3rd SL and in broad contact with the nasal and prefrontal, always separated from the internasal by the prefrontal; 8 / 8 supralabials, all entire; 1st–3rd SL tall, narrow and curved upwards and backwards, 1st and 2nd SL in contact with nasal, 2nd–3rd SL in contact with the loreal, 3rd and 4th SL in contact with preocular, 4th and 5th SL entering orbit, 7th SL largest; 1 / 1 small preocular; no subocular; 2 / 2 postoculars, subequal in size; 1 / 1 anterior temporal, relatively large, followed by 2 / 2 secondary temporals and 3 / 3 tertiary temporals, the combinations being 1+2+3 temporals; 10 / 10 infralabials, first pair in contact behind the small mental scale, 1st–5th / 1st–5th infralabials in contact with the first pair of chin shields, 1st–3rd IL narrow, 6th IL largest on both sides; 2 pairs of chin shields, elongate, the anterior one longer; chin shields of the posterior pair separated from each other by 2 intergenial scales on each side.

Coloration and pattern . The background color of the dorsum and sides of the body, above the 2nd or 3rd dorsal scale row, is uniform blackish-brown; dorsal scales with narrow paler margins; scales of the 1st–3rd DSR anteriorly, 1st–2nd DSR posteriorly uniform pale ochre-yellow; the dorsal-to-ventral color changes gradually on scales of the 2nd or 3rd DSR. The dorsal surface of the tail is uniform blackish-brown like the dorsal surface.

The head is uniform blackish-brown; edges of cephalic scales paler brown; lower part of 1st–8th supralabials ochre-yellow; upper part of these supralabials as the dorsal surface of the head. The throat, chin and infralabials are pale ochre-yellow; outer tip of infralabials of the first pair and inner part of the 2nd to 5th infralabials clouded with dark brown; inner margin of anterior chin shields also clouded with dark brown.

The venter is ochre-yellow, slightly darker posteriorly, mostly uniform but, on the posterior two thirds of the length of the venter, a series of round or semi-circular spots aligned on the anterior edge on the middle of most ventrals. The ventral surface of the tail is as the venter with a conspicuous, dark greyish-brown median longitudinal stripe following the track of the inner sutures of the subcaudals and shaped like a zigzag; this stripe extends along the entire length of tail.

sec.title: Paratype . NMW 18726:2 ( Fig. 2A–2D )
sec.p: Measurements . Female; SVL 187 mm , TaL 31 mm , TL 218 mm ; ratio TaL/TL 0.142; HL 12.7 mm ; HW 8.3 mm ; DE: 1.6 mm ; DE-L 1.7 mm ; DE-N 1.7 mm .

Morphology . As for the holotype , except: snout 2.0 times as long as the horizontal diameter of the eye; eye small, its diameter 0.95 times the distance between the lower margin of the eye and the edge of the lip.

Body scalation . Dorsal scales in 19 - 19 - 17 rows, normal in shape, all smooth; scales of the 1st DSR distinctly enlarged; 126 ventral plates (plus 1 preventral); 37 subcaudals, paired; cloacal plate divided.

Head scalation . As for the holotype , except: single internasal 1.8 times wider than long; frontal 1.6 times longer than wide, 2.4 times longer than the prefrontals; supraocular 1.8 times longer than wide, 0.7 times as wide as the frontal; parietals large, elongate, in broad contact with each other, 1.5 times longer than the frontal; 8 / 8 supralabials, arranged as in the holotype ; 2 / 2 anterior temporals, the lower one small, followed by 3 / 3 secondary temporals and 3 / 3 tertiary temporals, the combinations being 2+3+3 temporals; 11 / 10 infralabials, first pair in contact behind the small mental scale, 1st–6th / 1st–5th infralabials in contact with the first pair of chin shields.

Coloration and pattern . The colors and patterns of the body, head and venter are similar to those of the holotype . The soles differences bear on the pattern of the throat, chin and infralabials, more strongly and extensively marked with dark brown, and the more conspicuous median, zigzag-like stripe on the under surface of the tail.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
The homalopsid species
Enhydris plumbea
, then known as
Hypsiscopus plumbeus
, has been extensively cited in the literature about snakes of Southeast Asia. In this literature, this species has only the two junior synonyms. The first one is
Hypsirhina hardwickii Gray, 1835
( in 1832–1835: Plate 87: Fig. 1 . Type locality. None given), which has sometimes been used in the literature (for example by BOULENGER 1896). However, the type locality of this species is unknown. Furthermore, based on morphological characters of the depicted specimen, it is not possible to decide if it should be identified as
Hypsiscopus plumbeus
or
Hypsiscopus murphyi
. The second synonym is
Helicops wettsteini Amaral, 1929
.
showed that the type locality in Costa Rica is erroneous but that the types of this species should be referred to as
Enhydris plumbea
, now
Hypsiscopus plumbeus
.

divided
H. plumbeus sensu lato
into two species. These authors retained the former combination for populations inhabiting southern Thailand , Peninsular Malaysia and the Sunda Region, including Sulawesi. They referred populations of Central Thailand , most of Indochinese region and southern China to a new species,
Hypsiscopus murphyi Bernstein, Voris, Stuart, Phimmachak, Seateun, Sivongxay, Neang, Karns, Andrews, Osterhage, Phipps & Ruane, 2022
(565, Fig. 1 –4, Supplemental Fig. 1 –9. Type locality. Ban Phak Phoung, 17.581918°N- 105.219978°E , Gnommalath District, Khammouan Province , Laos , 167 m a.s.l. Holotype . NCSM 85490, adult male; collected by Bryan L. Stuart, Niane Sivongxay, Sengvilay Seateun and Monekham Davanhkham, 11 July 2014 .).

Besides genetic differences recovered by
in their phylogenetic tree, these authors mentioned the number of ventral plates as the main morphological difference between
H. murphyi
and
H. plumbeus
, namely 122–142 (our data) vs. 113–123, respectively.

However,
did not discuss the synonymy of
Hypsiscopus plumbeus
, and thus, overlooked the existence of the taxon
Helicops wettsteini
. In Table 1 , we summarize the main diagnostic characters of
Hypsiscopus plumbeus
and
H. murphyi
, both according to the definitions given by
, and variation in types of
Helicops wettsteini
. We did not include
Hypsiscopus matannensis (Boulenger, 1897)
in our table as this species, endemic to Sulawesi Island, has 21 DSR at midbody.

Based on these morphological characters, it appears that the numbers of ventral plates of the name-bearing types of
Helicops wettsteini
fall within the variation observed in
Hypsiscopus murphyi
, and not in the number of
Hypsiscopus plumbeus
. As
regarded the numbers of ventral plates as the sole visible morphological character separating these two species, we here synonymize
Hypsiscopus murphyi Bernstein, Voris, Stuart, Phimmachak, Seateun, Sivongxay, Neang, Karns, Andrews, Osterhage, Phipps & Ruane, 2022
with
Helicops wettsteini Amaral, 1929
, a combination which has priority as
Hypsiscopus wettsteini
new combination
.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p:
Following the erection of a new combination, the synonymies of
Hypsiscopus plumbeus
and
Hypsiscopus wettsteini
should be established as follows:

kwd.tp:taxon-name: Hypsiscopus murphyi Bernstein, Voris, Stuart, Phimmachak, Seateun, Sivongxay, Neang, Karns, Andrews, Osterhage, Phipps & Ruane, 2022: 565

Homalopsis plumbea ” Schlegel, 1826a: 238
(Species nomen credited to Kuhl & Van Hasselt).—

.

Homalopsis plumbea ” Schlegel, 1826b
: column 293 (Species nomen credited to Kuhl & Van Hasselt).—
Type locality. “Java” by inference.—Status. Nomen nudum , no description
.

Homalopsis plumbea H. Boie

.—

(at least 2 specimens ). (1) According to Gyi (1970: 82 ; but see the discussion below): specimen RMNH . RENA .1163, a female; deposited by Heinrich Kuhl and Johan Coenraad van Hasselt , 1820–1823.— (2) Specimen not traced
.

kwd.tp:taxon-name: Hypsiscopus murphyi Bernstein, Voris, Stuart, Phimmachak, Seateun, Sivongxay, Neang, Karns, Andrews, Osterhage, Phipps & Ruane, 2022: 565

mixed-citation.named-content: On the status of Helicops wettsteini Amaral, 1929, a senior synonym of Hypsiscopus murphyi (SERPENTES: Homalopsidae)

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Helicops wettsteini Amaral, 1929: 40
.— Type locality . “
San Juan de Viñas (1000 ms alt.), base of Volcano Turialba , central Costa Rica”, now Turrialba Volcano , Cartago Province , Costa Rica , in error.—
Holotype
. NMW 18726 , adult female; collected by Mr. Garlepp , 1911–1912.

Hypsiscopus murphyi Bernstein, Voris, Stuart, Phimmachak, Seateun, Sivongxay, Neang, Karns, Andrews, Osterhage, Phipps & Ruane, 2022: 565
,
–4, Supplemental
–9.—Type locality. Ban Phak Phoung , 17.581918°N- 105.219978°E , Gnommalath District , Khammouan Province , Laos ,
167 m a.s.l.
— Holotype . NCSM 85490, adult male; collected by Bryan L. Stuart , Niane Sivongxay , Sengvilay Seateun and Monekham Davanhkham ,
11 July 2014
.

We take the opportunity of the present paper to discuss the name-bearing type series of
Homalopsis plumbea H. Boie
in F. Boie, 1827 . This species was described from an unknown number of syntypes , but at least two syntypes as can be ascertained from F. Boie’s (1827) text in which he mentioned two values of subcaudal scales. We did not try to trace these original name-bearing types but Gyi’s (1970: 82) statement that specimen RMNH.RENA.1163 should be considered the holotype is erroneous. Furthermore, Murphy & Voris (2014) also overlooked that there were at least two syntypes and followed Gyi (1970) in mentioning a holotype .
Wallach et al . (2014: 268)
considered that Gyi (1970) designated a lectotype . However, according to Art. 74.5 of the Code (I. C. Z. N. 1999), this statement is also erroneous as the “subsequent use of the term ‘holotype’ does not constitute a valid lectotype designation”. The second part of Art. 74.5 being irrelevant to the present case, Gyi’s use of the term “ holotype ” cannot constitute the designation of a lectotype . Furthermore, following Art. 74.6, as the original description clearly implies that there were at least two specimens , there cannot be here a fixation of lectotype by inference of “ holotype ”. We follow Gyi (1970) in considering specimen RMNH.RENA.1163 as one of the two syntypes .

It remains to be established how two specimens of an Asian species were deposited as coming from Costa Rica . The two types of
Helicops wettsteini
were collected by “Garlepp”, namely either Gustav Garlepp (1862– 1907) or, much more likely, his brother Otto Garlepp (1864–1959), two noted German naturalist and professional collectors, mainly of insects and birds, in Neotropical America from 1883 (
Beolens et al . 2009
). Otto Garlepp, after having collected in South America, returned to Germany in 1911. Then, in 1912–1913, he shipped to Switzerland lepidopterans collected in Panama and Costa Rica during the same expedition. In Costa Rica , O. Garlepp collected on the volcanoes Irazu and Turrialba. Quite interestingly, the types of
H . wettsteini
were stated to originate from “Volcan Turialba”, another spelling of Turrialba volcano, a large, active stratovolcano culminating at 3,340 meters a.s.l. We could not determine how Asian snakes were included in a collection from Costa Rica but the types of
Helicops wettsteini
, stated to have been deposited in 1911 or 1912, were seemingly catalogued just prior the shipment of specimens from Costa Rica done by Otto Garlepp in 1912 or 1913. We suggest that the two Asian specimens, left unattended or overlooked in some room of Vienna’s Museum of Natural History, were subsequently erroneously added to this collection by some less than diligent curator or technician. The consequence is that these specimens were invisible to specialists of Asian snakes as it would be highly improbable that anyone would find two Asian specimens deposited in a museum alleged to be from a Costa Rican expedition.

As a conclusion, we here stress two major points relevant to Systematics. The first one is the importance of accessible and careful curation of natural history collections so that authors are able to easily determine what the proper taxonomy of these specimens is. The second point is the importance of establishing the complete synonymy of any taxon of species-level before dividing it into two or more species, and of examining carefully the diagnostic characters of all these synonyms. Such a careful synonymy might reveal available senior synonyms, which would avoid the creation of a new systematic nomen .

Hypsiscopus wettsteini
( n = 29).
